"Even as an agnostic atheist, I personally don't remove myself from the spiritual or the metaphysical, or from faith. I guess my biggest point of contention is the Judeo-Christian concept of God, even in its most basic (read: most removed from biblical texts) and distilled form. It seems a very human construct, and it seems that most of the universe is unquestionably alien to the human condition. I have my own beliefs on topics that typically fall under the scope of religion, which differ wildly from most established religions. More than anything, I think science fiction has helped to shape these ideas for me.

Although I think I am much less of a rationalist, I will agree with Chris in one respect, in that I feel that the idea of a God can be an inquiry-stifling thing. More than "the sciences", I ascribe to Science as a skeptical mental and philosophical mode of life. Constantly questioning, developing new explanations, testing them, doubting them, pitting them against new ones. Even with the things I have faith in, I try and be open to new, better, more concise, or better-supported ideas. To me, faith is based on our instinctual reaction to things we can't (or at least, don't currently) know. Even without a theistic mindset, there are things that resound within me as true, even without proof or the ability to prove. And there is a profound awe-inspiring beauty to me in things that seem beyond our knowledge or comprehension.

Perhaps this sounds like a spiritual view, and I would agree that it is. But back to the original point, I see no need for a God in any strict or loose sense to validate it. There are so many more clever and elegant answers. And to say, how can you answer questions "the sciences" could never provide evidence for, is to miss the point."

PART TWO:

"I am more prone to believe quantum physics than the Bible, mostly because quantum physics has withstood closer scrutiny. Besides it being predicated on a solid foundation of a few hundred years of previous scientific research, it has been extensively tested and revised. Shit, one of the uncertainty principles reduces elegantly to the formula for the diffraction of light, a phenomenon which has been observed and described for a long time now. It's a well-tested theory that concisely explains observed phenomena. Conversely, I would argue that the Bible is a single point of data, and is not just untested but has provoked a long history of suppressing those who question it. And even conceding that God did speak to man back in the day, and further that Jesus was real and the son of God, what evidence do we have that the Bible provides an accurate account of their stories and decrees? It's been shown that there are different versions of the Bible, some books were included or excluded due to human discretion, some parts lost, etc. And I can't think of too many compelling ways in which it explains observed phenomena. From a purely epistemological standpoint, I have trouble buying into it.

To be clear I'm not trying to bash religious texts of any sort, but I choose to believe things according to metrics of justification that make sense to me. And I believe many of these metrics are common to most humans in some form or another. Your friend claims he can fly? You look at precedent: you have a lot of evidence to suggest no human has ever been capable of doing so. You evaluate the evidence at hand: right now, it's just his word. You try and verify: can he show you now? You consult others to help verify: has anyone else seen this guy fly? You think of alternative explanations for the evidence: perhaps he is lying to you, as a joke, to impress you, etc. Which hypothesis seems more likely? Put in formal terms like this it may seem like an unnatural response, but when confronted with scenarios like this I believe this is how our brains handle it behind the scenes. I don't particularly care which side of the a/theist argument you agree with, I think the important part is having critical reasons for it."

One time walking back from class I was thinking about my thoughts and it seemed as if my memory kept throwing out little snippets of information, like the end of a thread of memory or some internal construct of thought, constantly and in bulk.  My thoughts seemed to be forming from some other part of my brain that was discerning, and would grab particular threads of information or memory or whatever according to internal patterns that it had learned as I grew up, and tied them together into thoughts.

I think the reason I don't hate myself is thus:

I have this ideal of who I should be, how I should act.  A perfect me, someone I would be okay with being.  I try and act like him as much as possible; even when it's difficult, especially when it's something that goes against what I personally would do.  That way, when I think about myself, I have all these points of data of when I was someone I don't hate.

"All I require from you is a sliver of a moment. To have you not by
force, but simply as a man and a woman. To see in your eyes, that simple
truth, that you give yourself to me freely. Not because you have to, but
because you want to. Now of course, for such a gem, I will give as
well. I'm willing to give you freedom. Pure and total freedom. Freedom
from the drudgery of everyday life. Freedom as abstract ideal. Freedom
from pain. Freedom from responsibility. Freedom from guilt. From regret.
Freedom from sadness. Freedom from loss. The freedom to be happy. Don't
close your eyes; I need you to look at me. The freedom to love."

"The best thing for being sad," replied Merlyn, beginning to puff and blow, "is to learn something. That's the only thing that never fails. You may grow old and trembling in your anatomies, you may lie awake at night listening to the disorder of your veins, you may miss your only love, you may see the world about you devastated by evil lunatics, or know your honour trampled in the sewers of baser minds. There is only one thing for it then — to learn. Learn why the world wags and what wags it. That is the only thing which the mind can never exhaust, never alienate, never be tortured by, never fear or distrust, and never dream of regretting. Learning is the only thing for you. Look what a lot of things there are to learn."



"The boy thought that there was something wrong with him.  All through his life - even when he was a great man with the world at his feet - he was to feel this gap: something at the bottom of his heart of which he was aware, and ashamed, but which he did not understand."

"His Word was valuable to him not only because he was good but also because he was bad. It is the bad people who need to have principles to restrain them."

"Finally, there was the impediment of his nature. In the secret parts of his peculiar brain, those unhappy and inextricable tangles which he felt at the roots, the boy was disabled by something which we cannot explain. He could not have explained either, and for us it is all too long ago. He loved Arthur and he loved Guenever and he hated himself. The best knight of the world: everybody envied the self-esteem which must surely be his. But Lancelot never believed he was good or nice. Under the grotesque, magnificent shell with a face like Quasimodo's, there was shame and self-loathing which had been planted there when he was tiny, by something which it is now too late to trace. It is so fatally easy to make young children believe that they are horrible."

I feel like the mind eats away at itself when given nothing else to process.

I had a strange idea, a sense, a paradigm that I happened upon in the bathroom.  That every moment of your life plays out as a dramatic story, a Hollywood blockbuster, a weft of thematic elements that open and close before the moment's up.  That deep and meaningful themes are explored and by the climax you are worn out- and then you leave the room and it starts again.  Just the thought makes me world-weary.  To have everything be bloated with importance seems tiresome.  There would be no rest, just a string of... of storied, mental orgasms.  What a terrible existence.
I think older me is the one adult I have complete control over.

Childhood is a tease.  All the things you take for granted, all the stuff that is given to you, all the money your parents spend feeding you and grooming you and entertaining you and indulging you and fulfilling you.  To be raised in such an environment, I think that was what made the transition to the "real world" the hardest.  Year after year there was a growing feeling that things were harder than they used to be, that you got less for free, that the world was slowly getting worse for you.
